Summary: The proposal aims to develop biologically plausible computational models of attention by integrating oscillatory dynamics, neuromodulation, and predictive coding. It seeks to bridge the gap between deep learning models and cognitive neuroscience, validating the model's neural plausibility and cognitive performance.
Strengths: Ambitious and original hypothesis integrating neuroscience and computational models.
Strong emphasis on neural plausibility and cognitive performance benchmarking.
Weaknesses: Potential challenges in scalability and computational efficiency of the hybrid architecture.
Lack of detail on baseline selection and fair comparisons in benchmarking.
High technical risk in implementing spiking neural networks with surrogate gradients.
Questions: How will the hybrid architecture ensure computational efficiency while maintaining biological fidelity?
What specific datasets will be used for benchmarking, and how will the baselines be selected to ensure fair comparisons?
What are the expected computational resource requirements for training and inference?
Limitations: Scalability of the hybrid architecture may be limited by computational resources.
The proposed model may face challenges in real-time performance due to the complexity of spiking neural networks.
Generalization to naturalistic tasks may be constrained by the availability of multimodal datasets.
